item.title: Ticket #7263 (Incorrect Error Message When Users Attempt to Add API Key using WP Stats) created
item.dc:creator: bubel
item.description:
Incorrect Error Message When Users Attempt to Add API Key of a user who is not on the blog's access list.

When a user attempts to add the API key of another user who is not on the blog's access list, an incorrect error message is displayed.

For instance, if user A wanted to add user B's API Key to a blog, an error message will display is user B is not on the blog's access list. However, the error message will read:

Error from last API Key attempt: The owner of that API Key (user A) is not on the access list for this blog (blog_id_goes_here). To be added to the access list, you must contact support.

The error message should display user B instead of user A.

item.title: Ticket #7262 (Use Firefox 3.5 native offline cache to add "turbo" functionality) created
item.dc:creator: mfinkle
item.description:
Recent Wordpress releases add a "turbo" feature that uses Gears local cache to store many static resources locally and increases the overal performance of the admin panel.

Firefox 3.1 will support the same functionality natively, without the need for a plugin. WordPress could streamline it's user experience and minimize dependencies if it used the new Firefox feature.

​http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Offline_resources_in_Firefox discusses how the offline resources work in Firefox. Firefox 3.0 did not support enough of the HTML5 offline spec to enable this feature for WordPress, but Firefox 3.1 will and the feature will appear in nightly versions of Firefox 3.1 soon.

item.title: Ticket #7261 (Press This) created
item.dc:creator: paulhontz
item.description:
When creating a new post from "Press This", the article does not link back to the original source if you click on the picture tab. If however, you stay on the default tab of text and press the link button, it will work.

These features are very important to tumblogs, or if you link to lots of blogs.

item.title: Ticket #7257 (Create hook for between the rss/atom and channel elements in feeds) updated
item.dc:creator: craigandrews
item.description:
I'm attaching a patch with adds three new hooks: rss_before_channel rss2_before_channel commentsrss2_before_channel

I think the names are pretty self-explanatory. No hooks are needed for atom, as atom_head covers the "before channel" case.

item.title: feed-atom-comments-head.patch attached to Ticket #7258
item.dc:creator: craigandrews
item.description: Add "atom_head" hook use

item.title: Ticket #7258 (feed-atom-comments.php should call atom_head hook) created
item.dc:creator: craigandrews
item.description: It seems to me that the "atom_head" hook should be called by feed-atom-comments.php as it is in feed-atom.php. Attached is a patch that provides this change.

item.title: Ticket #7257 (Create hook for between the rss/atom and channel elements in feeds) created
item.dc:creator: craigandrews
item.description:
To use Blogline's "access restriction," an xml element must be inserted immediately before the "channel" tag opens, or immediately after it closes. Right now, there are no hooks to do that.

Can you add such hooks?

Here is the documentation for access:restriction in bloglines: ​http://www.bloglines.com/about/specs/fac-1.0

Thanks!

item.title: Ticket #7256 (lostpassword does not work, ancillary fix) created
item.dc:creator: jonathan_v
item.description:
several bugfix tickets are addressing the fact that the lost password function is broken

the cause of the bug , is that wp_generate_password uses these chars: 

"abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789!@#$%^&*()"

while reset_password only uses these: 

[^a-z0-9]

i'd like to suggest an ancillary approach to fixing this - to complement whatever method is chosen:

in pluggable.php, i think wp_generate_password should be met with a function wp_validate_password.

then in reset_password, we replace 

$key = preg_replace('/[^a-z0-9]/i', '', $key);

with 

$key = wp_validate_password( $key );

then, the next time someone alters the wp_generate_password function , it can be quickly met for validation with unit tests and they'd see the 'validate_password' function right there.

item.title: Ticket #6518 (Shortcode escaping) updated
item.dc:creator: stringfold
item.description:
Replying to stringfold:

I agree that this is a problem that needs fixing. (Was a real pain for me until I found a workaround). I would favor the shortcode ? format and not those tick marks (unless WP starts using them elsewhere).

I wrote a workaround for my plugin (AZIndex). I simply added another parameter to my shortcode escape="true" for when I wanted to display the shortcode unmodified (in plugin documentation, for example).

But it would be nice to see this fixed in the next release.

Oops -- ? is the escape format I favor.

item.title: Ticket #6518 (Shortcode escaping) updated
item.dc:creator: stringfold
item.description:
I agree that this is a problem that needs fixing. (Was a real pain for me until I found a workaround). I would favor the shortcode? format and not those tick marks (unless WP starts using them elsewhere).

I wrote a workaround for my plugin (AZIndex). I simply added another parameter to my shortcode escape="true" for when I wanted to display the shortcode unmodified (in plugin documentation, for example).

But it would be nice to see this fixed in the next release.
